5. Discussion 293
5.1 Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca in bulk sediments of GeoB3228-1 294
Fe and Ti within marine sediment cores can be used as tracers of the siliciclastic 295
components of terrestrial sediments, and vary proportionally to the terrigenous fraction, 296
whereas Ca is largely derived from biogenic CaCO3 shell material (i.e., mostly pteropods, 297
foraminifera, and calcareous nannoplankton) (Govin et al., 2012). Elemental ratios 298
including Ca (e.g., Fe/Ca) are sensitive to dilution effects (i.e., enhanced biological 299
productivity, carbonate dissolution), which can affect reconstructions of terrestrial climate. 300
Nevertheless, in our record, post depositional carbonate dissolution and/or overgrowth were 301
not observed and could be ruled out, validating the use of Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca to discuss 302
marine versus terrigenous input as described below. 303
We assume that Ca fluxes remained relatively constant throughout the recorded 304
period. Only a few studies investigated changes in paleoproductivity in the oligothrophic 305
western South Atlantic Ocean (i.e., Mahiques et al., 2007; Nagai et al., 2010; Toledo, 2008; 306
Toledo et al., 2007). Toledo (2008) developed their work in an area affected by the Cabo 307
Frio upwelling system (Mahiques et al., 2005) and the changes in productivity were mainly 308
attributed to increased/decreased upwelling, which do not necessarily correspond to oceanic 309
conditions in our study area. Mahiques et al. (2007) and Nagai et al. (2010) found increased 310
productivity during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 23 to 19 ka, Mix et al., 2001) and 311
relatively stable paleoproductivity values during Termination 1. Even during the LGM our 312
Fe/Ca and Ti/Ca log ratios remained stable, which led us to assume that possible 313
productivity changes during our our studied time window did not affect our signal. 314
Sea level rise, however, appears to have modulated our signal. Each of the 315
progressively younger decreases in ln(Ti/Ca) has a higher amplitude in relationship to the 316
previous one, consistent with progressive distancing of the river mouth from the study site 317
due to sea level rise. Between 23 and 12 ka, sea level rose around 65m globally (e.g., 318
Lambeck and Chappell, 2001), with the highest sea level change rates occurring during 319
Melt Water Pulse 1A (MWP1A, Deschamps et al., 2012). MWP1A began at ~14.65 ka and 320
was synchronous to the onset of the BA. At ~14.7 ka, there is indeed a sharp decrease in 321
our Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca records (Figure 4). 322
Previous works have used Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca ratios to trace changes in terrigenous 323
input of fluvial origin of South American rivers, particularly offshore the semiarid 324
northeastern Brazil, where repeated authors pointed out increases in the terrigenous input 325
during Heinrich events due to southward shifts of the ITCZ (Arz et al., 1999; 1998; 326
Jaeschke et al., 2007; Jennerjahn et al., 2004; Nace et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2015). 327
In comparison to these studies though, we observe a different trend in our data. The 328
noticeable features of our records are the lower terrigenous excursions centered at 20.08, 329
18.37, 16.38, 15.23 and 13.65 ka representing decrease in terrigenous input to the basin, 330
which translate into dry periods in the catchment area and decreased Doce River runoff. 331
Curiously, Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca remained stable even during time windows when we would 332
expect SASM related terrigenous input to increase (e.g., Stríkis et al., 2015). This can be 333
tentatively explained by three hypotheses, explored on subsection 5.3. 334
The most prominent features observed in our curves is by far the long standing 335
decrease in Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca between 15.5 ka and 12.5 ka, which starts before the BA (at 336
14.7 ka) and ends with ratios increasing again almost to plateau values during the Younger 337
Dryas (YD). 338
5.2 ?18O in stalagmites from Lapa Sem Fim Cave 339
Speleothem ?18O in tropical and subtropical lowlands is usually interpreted as a 340
precipitation proxy, indicating changes in precipitation source (Cruz et al., 2006; 2005) 341
and/or amount (Bony et al., 2008; Risi et al., 2008). The first imply that moisture becomes 342
progressively impoverished in 18O as further away from its source it travels, and the second 343
describes the negative correlation between monthly rainfall amount and monthly weighted 344
mean ?18O. Given that in the LSF area 90% of the annual precipitation is related to SASM 345
activity, negative (positive) anomalies in ?18O from LSF stalagmites have been interpreted 346
to reflect increases (decreases) in precipitation, that, in turn, are related with higher (lower) 347
intensity of the SASM (Stríkis et al., 2015; 2011). 348
Based on this assumption, our ?18O signal shows neither too wet nor too dry 349
conditions between 23 and 18.1 ka. The most remarkable feature during this period being a 350
drier excursion between 20.64 and 20.13 ka (which is also related with the smallest growth 351
rate in our record, the 1.54 cm/kyr between 20.43 and 19.35 ka). 352
Between 14.7 ka and 13.15 ka, the LSF15 ?18O signal can be divided in three phases 353
representing two drier excursions separated by a relatively wet one, correspondent to the 354
Bølling (14.7 - 14.13 ka), Older Dryas (14.13-13.86 ka) and Allerød (13.86 – 13.15 ka) 355
periods, in chronological order (period names according to Mangerud et al., 1974). On 356
LSF15 between 13.15 and 12 ka, ?18O are more negative, pointing to SASM intensification 357
right before and during the YD. It is worthy of note that the LSF record presented here is 358
the most detailed record describing precipitation changes within the Bølling–Allerød 359
interstadial in South America. 360
5.3 Integrating elemental ratios and stable isotopes 361
LSF ?18O records 8 excursions toward less negative values that are synchronous to 362
decreases on Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca from GeoB3228-1 (with the exception of one, at 17.20 ka) 363
(Figure 5). This confirms that excursions toward less negative values on our speleothem 364
record are connected with runoff decrease in the Doce River Basin, as shown by the 365
decreases on Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca. Since over 80% of the rainfall on the Doce River basin and 366
Lapa Sem Fim Cave is brought by SASM, we interpret that during these periods the 367
monsoon intensity was weakened, likely connected with decrease in moisture influx caused 368
by relatively northward positioning of the ITCZ. 369
However, the inverse seems not to be valid, i.e., excursions toward more negative 370
?18O values on LSF are not related to increased Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca log ratios on GeoB3228-1. 371
There are two possibly related hypotheses to explain this apparent mismatch, each 372
involving one of our proxies. 373
First, decreases in stable isotopes ratios in speleothems formed under ideal 374
conditions (i.e., calcite crystallization in isotopic equilibrium with drop water isotopic 375
content) are produced by the amount effect (i.e., 18O impoverishment on rainfall moisture 376
linearly correlated with the amount of rainfall (Bony et al., 2008; Risi et al., 2008)) over the 377
karstic system or along the moisture path since its departure from the reservoir, which is 378
primarily the ocean. Hence, calcite isotopic composition is not necessarily only a recorder 379
of precipitation amount over the cave itself, as the moisture can have been depleted 380
progressively and unequally along its pathway from the reservoir. In this scenario, 381
increased precipitation over the Amazon due to southward ITCZ shifts would already 382
transmit 18O-poor moisture to areas under SACZ influence without necessarily increasing 383
rainfall amount over the cave. 384
385
Second, different weathering patterns and sediment transport between densely 386
vegetated tropical eastern SA and the semiarid areas should also be considered. As 387
mentioned above, previous studies that assessed shifts in precipitation and the related 388
changes in Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca were carried out off northeastern Brazil (Arz et al., 1998; 389
Jaeschke et al., 2007; Jennerjahn et al., 2004; Nace et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2015). That 390
area is characterized by semiarid climate (Bsh, Köppen-Geiger climate type, Peel et al., 391
2007) which favor a fast response of the terrigenous input to oceanic basins for several 392
reasons. As the countryside is usually hot and dry, the landscape is dominated by relatively 393
sparse savanna vegetation (Cole, 1960; Machado et al., 1997) and shallow rock-soil 394
interface (Bétard et al., 2007). Under these conditions, abrupt floods or increased rainfall 395

In this scenario, weathering profiles are better fixated and to some extent protected from 399

Relying on either one of these hypotheses does not affect our conclusions, that 404
central eastern SA experienced extremely drier than average conditions at specific periods 405
during Termination I and LGM, most prominently during the BA. We suggest that these 406
drier periods were related to weakened intensity of SASM. 407
5.4 The Bølling-Allerød interstadial in South America 408
A northward shift of the ITCZ during the BA (see Deplazes et al., 2013) and 409
references therein) would have decreased the moisture influx to the SASM, decreasing also 410
its intensity and, consequently the amount of precipitation in our study area. 411
We further compared our Ti/Ca and ?18O records with the output of the 412
SYNTRACE run of the CCSM3 fully-coupled climate model with transient forcing for the 413
last deglaciation or Termination I (45°W to 37°W, 20°S to 13°S, Liu et al., 2009) (Figure 414
6a). In this simulation, the HS1 increase in precipitation over the region of the Rio Doce 415
Basin was relatively smaller than the abrupt decrease due to the onset of the BA. Also, in 416
agreement with our results, the BA was the driest period within 23 and 12 ka. The model, 417
however, does show the earlier transition to drier conditions in the end of HS1 and before 418
the BA, as shown by Ti/Ca ratios in our marine sediment core. We assume this happens 419
because the model was elaborated mainly with Northern Hemispheric forcings (Liu et al., 420
2009) that exclude the regional variations which can have caused such earlier SASM 421
intensity decrease in the end of the HS1. 422
The marine sediment cores GeoB3129-1 and GeoB3911-3 (Arz et al., 1999; 423
Jennerjahn et al., 2004; Weldeab et al., 2006) (Figure 6e), were collected off northeastern 424
Brazil, where southward shifts of the ITCZ resulted in increased terrigenous input (Fe/Ca 425
ratios). Fe/Ca composite from cores GeoB3129-1 and GeoB3911-3 show the same 426
precipitation trend implied by LSF ?18O (Figure 6c) and similar to GeoB3228-1 Ti/Ca 427
(Figure 6d) and Fe/Ca ratios. The HS1 structure described by (Stríkis et al., 2015) can also 428
be recognized in the GeoB3129-1 / GeoB3911-3 Fe/Ca composite, showing a prominently 429
wet HS1c, followed by a dry excursion compatible with HS1b, a brief return to wetter 430
conditions in the beginning of the HS1a, followed by a transitional passage to drier 431
conditions that remain during the BA. On both GeoB3228-1 and GeoB3129-1 / GeoB3911-432
3 Fe/Ca composite the beginning of the Bølling period is indistinguishable from the end of 433
HS1a. The Fe/Ca increase (on GeoB3129-1/GeoB3911-3 composite) at 14 ka is relatable 434
with the LSF ?18O decrease between Bølling and Allerød periods, possibly explainable by a 435
brief southward shift of the ITCZ during the Older Dryas cold period in the Northern 436
Hemisphere. This southward shift would have briefly intensified SASM, reflecting as more 437
negative ?18O values on our Lapa Sem Fim Cave composite and not being recorded in our 438
marine sediment core due to the intrinsic characteristics of Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca ratios from 439
Doce River basin, already discussed in the previous subsection. 440
On GeoB3228-1 Ti/Ca and Fe/Ca ratios, the 14.7 ka abrupt decrease in the 441
terrigenous input can be connected to either a rapid decrease in SASM intensity or the fast 442
sea level rise during MWP1A (Deschamps et al., 2012). 443
The comparison between precipitation estimations from SYNTRACE run of the 444
CCSM3 (Liu et al., 2009), Fe/Ca from marine sediment cores GeoB3129-1 and GeoB3911-445
3 (Arz et al., 1999; Jennerjahn et al., 2004; Weldeab et al., 2006) and our coupled 446
GeoB3228-1 Ti/Ca and LSF ?18O allow us to confirm decreased SASM intensity in eastern 447
SA during the BA, likely related to northward positiong of ITCZ and consequent reduced 448
moisture influx to SASM. 449

6. Conclusion 451
The 2 kyr long Bølling-Allerød interstadial had a clear impact in South American 452
climate, leading to long standing dry conditions in central eastern South America. The 453
markedly dry conditions during Bølling-Allerød interstadial are related to weakened 454
intensity of the South American Summer Monsoon, likely caused by reduced moisture 455
influx to the continent due to the contemporaneous northward shift of Intertropical 456
Convergence Zone. 457
